This is the Mirror Formatting Guide!

- All of standard Markdown is supported, including `code` blocks, images, lists, etc‚Ä¶
- We have introduced enhanced parsing in certain cases to embed rich media blocks.

[Markdown Documentation](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax)

It is possible to embed an enhanced media block for certain links, provided the link sits in isolation on it‚Äôs own line. For instance‚Ä¶

```markdown
‚Ä¶not a great deal of common ground between this sound (as popularized on the post-Roll Deep Rinse and at Forward) and the Wiley/ Dizzee end of Grime/ Eski.‚Ä¶

![](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D1gl46hh3sQ)

It's partly a question of geography - the 'Grime' on display here is a South, rather than an East, London t'ing'‚Ä¶
```

Will render an embeded Youtube video, like so:

[Dizzee Rascal - Bassline Junkie](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D1gl46hh3sQ)

title: Formatting Guide
body:
We appreciate you being here early, and thank you for your patience as we improve Mirror. There‚Äôs a lot of work to do, and with that are certain compromises.

In this spirit, we have decided to implement a plain text editor with Markdown formatting, similar to pro favorites like [iA Writer](https://ia.net/writer). As such Mirror supports all of markdown, plus a few special extras.

For an extensive Markdown formatting guide, take a look at [Daring Fireball](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax).

## Media Blocks

Creating a media embed on Mirror is extremely simple:

1. Create a new line of text.
2. Add a link to anything.
3. Insert a line break.

It looks like this:

```markdown
The 90-minute presentation essentially demonstrated almost all the fundamental elements of modern personal computing:

[The Mother of All Demos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yJDv-zdhzMY)

Engelbart's presentation was the first to publicly demonstrate all of these elements in a single system.
```

As you‚Äôd guess, this creates a Youtube embed:

[The Mother of All Demos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FCiBUawCawo)

Simple, right? We‚Äôve decided to parse basic links‚Äîas opposed to introducing Mirror specific syntax‚Äîto ensure portability. If the markdown is rendered with Mirror you will see Media Blocks. If anywhere else, you‚Äôll see a simple plain text link. There are a number of integrations, and we‚Äôre adding more every week.

This is almost embarrassingly simple, but below is a comprehensive list.

---

### Link Previews

```md
[Mirror](https://mirror.xyz)
```

Mirror displays a progressively enhanced preview of all links based on the universal standard of [OpenGraph tags](https://ogp.me). This is the same standard you see on Twitter and Facebook.

[Mirror](https://mirror.xyz)

In this spirit, we‚Äôve decided to implement a plain text editor with Markdown formatting, similar to pro favorites like [iA Writer](https://ia.net/writer). This is in contrast to WYSIWYG editors like Notion. We came to this conclusion after speaking with a number of our favorite writers who require an easy way to go from their favorite writing app (like iA Writer) to Mirror, and also prioritize personal archivability.

As such Mirror supports all of markdown, plus a few special extras. For an extensive Markdown formatting guide, take a look at [Daring Fireball](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax). We aim to implement support for copy-and-paste between tools like Google Docs and platforms such as Medium. All in time üòå

*Note*: None of this is considered a permanent solution. There are already plans to deprecate this simplistic editor in favor of something more dynamic. These plans have no impact on the writing you do today‚Äîwe‚Äôll take care of migrating you when the time comes.

Let‚Äôs $WRITE.

## Media Blocks

Creating a media embed on Mirror is extremely simple:

1. Create a new line of text.
2. Add a link to anything.
3. Insert a line break.

It looks like this:

```markdown
The 90-minute presentation essentially demonstrated almost all the fundamental elements of modern personal computing:

[The Mother of All Demos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yJDv-zdhzMY)

Engelbart's presentation was the first to publicly demonstrate all of these elements in a single system.
```

As you‚Äôd guess, this creates a Youtube embed:

[The Mother of All Demos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FCiBUawCawo)

Simple, right? We‚Äôve decided to parse basic links‚Äîas opposed to introducing Mirror specific syntax‚Äîto ensure portability. If the markdown is rendered with Mirror you will see Media Blocks. If anywhere else, you‚Äôll see a simple plain text link. There are a number of integrations, and we‚Äôre adding more every week.

This is almost embarrassingly simple, but below is a comprehensive list.

---

### Link Previews

```md
[Mirror](https://mirror.xyz)
```

Mirror displays a progressively enhanced preview of all links based on the universal standard of [OpenGraph tags](https://ogp.me). This is the same standard you see on Twitter and Facebook.

[Mirror](https://mirror.xyz)

### Twitter

```md
[Mirror‚Äôs first tweet](https://twitter.com/viamirror/status/1325856116748726273)
```

[Mirror‚Äôs first tweet](https://twitter.com/viamirror/status/1325856116748726273)

### Youtube

```md
[Design jam on Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=geRPXByWV2U&feature=youtu.be)
```

[Design jam on Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=geRPXByWV2U&feature=youtu.be)

---

Are we missing an integration you‚Äôd like to see? Please don‚Äôt hesitate to [say hello](d@mirror.xyz)!

title: Foundation Myths and a Reflection on "The Social Network" Movie
body:
A decade before Facebook turned into a dominating global political institution and [banned the President of the United States](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/07/technology/facebook-trump-ban.html), *The Social Network* was filmed to depict its foundation story. Like all creation myths, it's not meant to be literal. These myths serve as dramatic representations to guide our intuitions about what an entity stands for. 

This is true for national epics like *The Aeneid* about the founding of Rome, which provided solid ground for a nation's moral values over centuries. It is also true for this haunting film, *The Social Network*, which cautions us about how to approach Facebook and the culture of Silicon Valley.

I watched the movie tonight, for the first time in years, and the salient themes today in the creation myth of Facebook, as depicted by David Fincher and Aaron Sorkin, are *envy* and *deception*. 

As we reflect on the thing Facebook has ultimate become, we realize that it's not our ability to connect, but to *compare* that is the driver of platform's engagement. And its ability to *deceive us* -- about how it is using and controlling us and our politics -- is how it continues to survive. 

Envy oozes into almost every scene in the movie: first, in Zuck's obsession with prestigious final clubs, like the one his best friend Edwardo is being invited to ("It's probably a diversity thing"; "Don‚Äôt be upset if you don‚Äôt go any further"). His environment at Harvard is characterized by a compulsion towards exclusivity, and that's how the projects gets its start -- as a quest to artificially amplify our desire to stand out among peers.

Within the first minute of the movie, we're asked: *How do you distinguish yourself in a population of people who all got 1,600 on their SATs*? Perhaps the emotional essence of that question echos each time a teenager in America open her Facebook or Instagram account.

Women in particular are used throughout the film to amplify the sense of judgement of status. 

Zuck is depicted in deceiving the Winklevoss twins -- not through lying, but through subtle evasion of the truth. Today, Facebook doesn't exactly *lie* about the [scandalous way that our data is being used](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/04/us/politics/cambridge-analytica-scandal-fallout.html) and their [practiced ability to control our emotions](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jun/29/facebook-users-emotions-news-feeds).

My point isn't that Facebook is bad. That's already been said. My point is that foundation myths are extremely important and we should pay attention to them. They're a deep part of human civilization. 

Also, the movie was excellent. I could explore its themes for hours more.

title: Editor Guide
body:
Mirror Editor `0.1.0` is a plain text markdown editor with support a simple formatting convention for rich media embeds, similar to pro favorite [iA Writer](https://ia.net/writer).

Markdown basics are supported, such as *italics*, **bold**, [links](https://mirror.xyz), `code`, block quotes, and more. For an extensive overview of Markdown formatting, head over to [Daring Fireball](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax).

> I don't think about technique. The ideas dictate everything.  
> ‚Äî David Lynch

```js
const name = 'Mirror'
console.log(`Clearly ${name} is the best`)
```

## Media Blocks

Creating a media embed on Mirror is extremely simple:

1. Create a new line of text.
2. Add a link to anything.
3. Insert a line break.

It looks like this:

```markdown
The 90-minute presentation essentially demonstrated almost all the fundamental elements of modern personal computing:

[The Mother of All Demos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yJDv-zdhzMY)

Engelbart's presentation was the first to publicly demonstrate all of these elements in a single system.
```

As you‚Äôd guess, this creates a Youtube embed:

[The Mother of All Demos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FCiBUawCawo)

Simple, right? We‚Äôve decided to parse basic links‚Äîas opposed to introducing Mirror specific syntax‚Äîto ensure portability. If the markdown is rendered with Mirror you will see Media Blocks. If anywhere else, you‚Äôll see a simple plain text link. There are a number of integrations, and we‚Äôre adding more every week.

This is almost embarrassingly simple, but below is a comprehensive list.

---

### Link Previews

```md
[Mirror](https://mirror.xyz)
```

Mirror displays a progressively enhanced preview of all links based on the universal standard of [OpenGraph tags](https://ogp.me). This is the same standard you see on Twitter, Facebook and other Jurassic platforms.

[Mirror](https://mirror.xyz)

### Twitter

```md
[Mirror‚Äôs first tweet](https://twitter.com/viamirror/status/1325856116748726273)
```

[Mirror‚Äôs first tweet](https://twitter.com/viamirror/status/1325856116748726273)

### Youtube

```md
[Design jam on Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=geRPXByWV2U&feature=youtu.be)
```

[Design jam on Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=geRPXByWV2U&feature=youtu.be)

---

A brief list of future enhancements:

- Support for copy-and-paste between tools like Google Docs and platforms such as Medium.
- Additional media block integrations.

Are we missing an integration you‚Äôd like to see? Please don‚Äôt hesitate to [say hello](d@mirror.xyz)!
